review.title: Network Traffic Decomposition for Anomaly Detection
review.abstract: In this paper we focus on the detection of network anomalies like Denial of Service (DoS) attacks and port scans in a unified manner. While there has been an extensive amount of research in network anomaly detection, current state of the art methods are only able to detect one class of anomalies at the cost of others. The key tool we will use is based on the spectral decomposition of a trajectory/hankel matrix which is able to detect deviations from both between and within correlation present in the observed network traffic data. Detailed experiments on synthetic and real network traces shows a significant improvement in detection capability over competing approaches. In the process we also address the issue of robustness of anomaly detection systems in a principled fashion.

sections.heading: 4 Network Anomaly Types
sections.text: A major contribution of our paper is that the M-SSA-based approach is capable of detecting almost all known types of network anomalies. In this section, we describe the different types of common anomalies and explain why M-SSA offers other anomalies. Table 1 lists the common anomalies that are defined as 5-fold using the flow (source IP address, destination IP address, source port number, destination port number, transport protocol); for more details, see Silveira et al (2010a, b); Lakhina et al (2005, 2004a). A Denial-of-Service (DoS) attack occurs when the attacking hosts send a large number of small packets - typically TCP-SYN segments - to the attacked host and service, i.e. a single IP address and port number in order to draw system resources from the target host with a relatively small amount of data flows resulting from a DoS attack.

sections.heading: 5 Experimental evaluation
sections.text: We have evaluated our proposed approach using both real and synthetic datasets and have implemented well-known network anomaly techniques based on wavelength, kalma filtering, Fourier analysis and the newer ASTUTE methodology for comparison. The use of synthetic datasets and simulations is a prerequisite for a rigorous evaluation strategy for detecting network anomalies (Ringberg et al (2008); Soule et al (2005); Silveira et al (2010a)).5.1 Detectability We evaluate the detectability of M-SSA using two real network tracks that we are now describing.

sections.heading: 5.1.1 Datasets
sections.text: The first traffic trace originates from the Abilene network1 and has previously been used to detect network anomalies (see Silveira et al (2010a, b); Lakhina et al (2005, 2004a))). The dataset consists of a one-month traffic trace from a backbone router in New York in August 2007. Juniper router captured the generated data at a sampling rate of 1 / 100. Data flows were aggregated at five-minute intervals, with the most important attributes of the flow being: number of packets, number of unique source IP addresses, number of unique destination IP addresses, number of different source port numbers and number of different destination port numbers. The second and most recent traffic trace comes from the MAWI (Measurement and Analysis on the WIDE Internet) Archive Project in Japan2.

sections.text: The ROC curves shown in Fig. 8 show that M-SSA has a higher true positive rate than all other techniques for a given false positive rate. sections.heading: 6 Related Work
sections.text: The current network infrastructure is protected against malicious attacks by signature-based intrusion detection systems (IDS) (Roesch (1999); Paxson (1998). However, it is widely known that attackers can bypass these systems by generating small modifications of known signatures. In principle, the biggest challenge is to offer anomaly-based detection systems (ADS) as an attractive alternative to signature-based systems.ADS are based on the notion of "statistical normality" and malicious events that cause deviations from normal behavior.The biggest challenge is to characterize the normal traffic that is subject to the compulsion of network traffic to exhibit non-stationary behavior. Existing techniques for ADS are based on decomposition methods of network time series. For example, Lakhina et al (2004b, a, 2005), the use of Principal Component Analysis (PCA) and the first dynamic connection to PCal (A) has caused al al to remote network detection.

sections.heading: 7 Conclusions
sections.text: In this paper, we have proposed a unified and robust method for detecting network anomalies based on Multivariate Singular Spectrum Analysis (M-SSA). Because M-SSA can detect deviations in both spatial and temporal correlations in data, it allows detection of both DoS and port scan attacks. A DoS attack is an example of time deviations, while a port scan attack violates spatial correlations. In addition to using M-SSA to detect network anomalies, we have conducted a comprehensive evaluation and compared M-SSA with other approaches based on wavelengths, Fourier analysis, calman filtering, and the recently introduced ASTUTE method. We have also conducted a rigorous analysis of the parameter configurations associated with the use of M-SSA, and addressed some of the important issues raised in the network community.

The mathematical basis of Singular Spectrum Analysis (SSA) is the celebrated result in nonlinear dynamics due to Takens et al (1981). Taken’s theorem asserts that the latent non-linear dynamics governing can be recovered using a delayed time embedding of the observable time series.

The first practical use of Taken’s theorem for time series analysis and the connection with spectral methods like singular value decomposition (SVD) was first proposed by Broomhead and King (1986a,c).
